user_message:
<misra_rule>
MISRA C 2023 Rule 2.1 is: A project shall not contain unreachable code.

</misra_rule>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- is_rule_violated: whether the rule is violated or not (true/false),
- scenario: a specific violation scenario.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of internal_add_connection:
```c
static enum MHD_Result
internal_add_connection (struct MHD_Daemon *daemon,
                         MHD_socket client_socket,
                         const struct sockaddr_storage *addr,
                         socklen_t addrlen,
                         bool external_add,
                         bool non_blck,
                         bool sk_spipe_supprs,
                         enum MHD_tristate sk_is_nonip)
{
  struct MHD_Connection *connection;

#if defined(MHD_USE_POSIX_THREADS) || defined(MHD_USE_W32_THREADS)
  /* Direct add to master daemon could never happen. */
  mhd_assert (NULL == daemon->worker_pool);
#endif

  if (MHD_D_IS_USING_SELECT_ (daemon) &&
      (! MHD_D_DOES_SCKT_FIT_FDSET_ (client_socket, daemon)) )
  {
#ifdef HAVE_MESSAGES
    MHD_DLOG (daemon,
              _ ("New connection socket descriptor (%d) is not less " \
                 "than FD_SETSIZE (%d).\n"),
              (int) client_socket,
              (int) MHD_D_GET_FD_SETSIZE_ (daemon));
#endif
    MHD_socket_close_chk_ (client_socket);
#if defined(ENFILE) && (ENFILE + 0 != 0)
    errno = ENFILE;
#endif
    return MHD_NO;
  }

  if (MHD_D_IS_USING_EPOLL_ (daemon) &&
      (! non_blck) )
  {
#ifdef HAVE_MESSAGES
    MHD_DLOG (daemon,
              _ ("Epoll mode supports only non-blocking sockets\n"));
#endif
    MHD_socket_close_chk_ (client_socket);
#if defined(EINVAL) && (EINVAL + 0 != 0)
    errno = EINVAL;
#endif
    return MHD_NO;
  }

  connection = new_connection_prepare_ (daemon,
                                        client_socket,
                                        addr, addrlen,
                                        external_add,
                                        non_blck,
                                        sk_spipe_supprs,
                                        sk_is_nonip);
  if (NULL == connection)
    return MHD_NO;

  if ((external_add) &&
      MHD_D_IS_THREAD_SAFE_ (daemon))
  {
    /* Connection is added externally and MHD is thread safe mode. */
    MHD_mutex_lock_chk_ (&daemon->new_connections_mutex);
    DLL_insert (daemon->new_connections_head,
                daemon->new_connections_tail,
                connection);
    daemon->have_new = true;
    MHD_mutex_unlock_chk_ (&daemon->new_connections_mutex);

    /* The rest of connection processing must be handled in
     * the daemon thread. */
    if ((MHD_ITC_IS_VALID_ (daemon->itc)) &&
        (! MHD_itc_activate_ (daemon->itc, "n")))
    {
#ifdef HAVE_MESSAGES
      MHD_DLOG (daemon,
                _ ("Failed to signal new connection via inter-thread " \
                   "communication channel.\n"));
#endif
    }
    return MHD_YES;
  }

  return new_connection_process_ (daemon, connection);
}
```
</target_code>
<target_code>
Here is the code fragment that you need to analyze:
```c
#if defined(ENFILE) && (ENFILE + 0 != 0)
    errno = ENFILE;
#endif
```
Focus on the above code fragment and judge whether it violates the rule 2.1 or not.
</target_code>
scenario: Not violated. The errno = ENFILE; statement is conditionally compiled only when the macro ENFILE is defined and evaluates to a non‑zero integer constant. When that condition holds the statement becomes ordinary executable code and can be reached at runtime, so it is not unreachable. (By contrast, a Rule 2.1 violation would occur if code were compiled into the translation unit but could never be executed on any control‑flow path — e.g. code placed after an unconditional return.)
